name: hard coal preparation, crushing and destoning | hard coal | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/18694/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of crushed and screened coal in South Africa. Around 34% of South Africa's saleable coal has undergone simple coal preparation only  (crushing and destoning) (SACRM, 2011). The crushed coal product is used almost exclusively by the domestic coal market, primarily in electricity generation and in the production of synthetic fuels and chemicals. Total production in 2014 amounted to 90 million tonnes (DMR, 2015). This dataset includes ONLY the waste produced, the land required for its disposal and methane emissions associated with coal crushing.This is because disaggregated data was not available for the mining operations, so energy use and preparation plant area are included in the coal mining datasets.Similarly, where generic mining factors have been used in the mining datasets (e.g. for particulates and infrastructure), these are assumed to include coal preparation. No addtional water use or emissions are assumed to arise from simple coal preparation. ;;Reference(s): ;SACRM (2011) Overview of South African Coal Value Chain. Available at: http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm value chain overview.pdf (Accessed: July 2015); ;DMR (2015) Mineral Production and Sales and Mining Labour Statistics Tables 1993 - 2014, Department of Mineral Resources. Available at: http://www.dmr.gov.za/ (Accessed: March 2017).;[This dataset is meant to replace the following datasets:]

Coal preparation (crushing and screening), starting from hard coal, run-of mine.

This activity ends with 1 kg hard coal (useable output) at the coal preparation facility. This dataset includes mining waste produced and land used for coal waste disposal, Energy use and land for the preparation plant are not included in this dataset as they are included in the mining datasets (they were not able to be disaggregated from the mining data). No water use or water emissions are attributed to the simple coal preparation process. Particulates are similarly not included because the generic value applied in the mining datasets is assumed to include coal preparation.
category: B:Mining and quarrying/05:Mining of coal and lignite/051:Mining of hard coal/0510:Mining of hard coal

processDocumentation.timeDescription: 2014 is chosen as a base year because this is the latest year for which coal production and yield data were available (i.e. the most recent government statistics on coal mining). The industry data on which the dataset is based is somewhat earlier than 2014 (mid 2000 to 2010), but expert opinion consulted is that mining operations have not changed much over this time, thus it made sense to use the most recent production data.
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Coal preparation efficiency is representative of coal mining in South Africa as a whole, with the land requirements for disposal extrapolated from colliereis mining the Witbank the Highveld coalfields in South Africa. Infrastructure requriements are generic (not South African specific).
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: This dataset is representative of simple coal preparation in South Africa (crushing and screening only), with an overall efficiency of 98%.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Production volume is from DMR (2015), with the percentage of coal undergoing crushing and the coal preparation efficiency from SACRM (2011). Methane emissions are calculated using post-mining emission factors derived for South Africa's national GHG reporting (DEA, 2014). Land use for dump areas are from three mines with crushing plants only. References: Department of Minerals and Resources (2015) South Africa's Mineral Industry (SAMI) 2014/2015. Pretoria; DEA (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf (accessed September 2017);  Pulles, W., Boer, R. & Nel, S. 2001. A Generic Water Balance for the South African Coal Mining Industry. Water 
Research Commission Report No. 801/1/01; SACRM (2011) Overview of South African Coal Value Chain. Available at: http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm value chain overview.pdf (Accessed: July 2015).

exchanges.description: Assumes active dump area lifetime of 30 years and revegetation time of 25 years. A relatively long time is chosen as dumps present the greatest challenge to rehabilitation of coal mines.

Overall coal preparation yield of 98% applied for coal undergoing crushing and destoning, resulting in 20 kg coal waste per tonne coal beneficiated. Yield applied is  average value from SACRM mine data sample (range from 89%-99%)), which aligns with industry expert estimate of 96% (Prevost, 2015).  Reference(s): The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf; Prevost X (2015) Coal chain, 2014 http://www.fossilfuel.co.za/conferences/2015/JCMV-X/Session-1/02Xavier-Prevost.pdf

exchanges.description: Hard coal supply from underground mines. A coal preparation yield of 98% is applied for coal undergoing crushing and destoning (average value from SACRM mine data sample, and aligns with industry expert estimate of 96% (Prevost, 2015). Using a combination of DMR (2015) and SACMR (2011) production statistics, coal supply to simple coal preparation (crushing and destoning) is as follows: 88% from underground mining, 8% for surface, dragline, and 4% from surface, truck and shovel.  Reference(s): The South African Coal Roadmap (SACRM) (2011). Overview of the South African Coal Value Chain. http://www.sanedi.org.za/archived/wp-content/uploads/2013/08/sacrm%20value%20chain%20overview.pdf; Prevost X (2015) Coal chain, 2014 http://www.fossilfuel.co.za/conferences/2015/JCMV-X/Session-1/02Xavier-Prevost.pdf

exchanges.description: Emission factor for low temperature oxidation of coal taken from South Africa's National GHG Inventory for post-mining coal handling and storage (0.18 m3/tonne, underground mine). Emission factor is for underground coal only, with surface coal given an emission factor of 0. The emissions are therefore adjusted for the percenatge of coal undergoing crushing and destoning supplied from surface mines. Reference:  Department of Environment (2014) GHG NATIONAL INVENTORY REPORT SOUTH AFRICA 2000 -2010, November 2014. http://unfccc.int/resource/docs/natc/zafnir1.pdf
